TextEquiv.Unicode: what largely out of the holy scripture,
to the intent I might prove to al men,
that wedlocke is holie, & that therefore
no ma can be defiled with ye moderate,
holie, & lawful use thereof: and so con
sequently that marriage is permitted
to al sorts of men. For ye Apostle saith:
Let a bishoppe be the husband of one
wife, let him rule his owne house wel,
and have faithfull children. For it is
manifest by ye testimonies of scripture
and ecclesiasticall writers, that the A
postles of Christ and other Apostolical
teachers of ye primitive Church were
married men, and had wives and chil
dren. Neither is there any thing, next
after corrupt doctrine, which doeth
more infect the Church of Christ, and
subvert al ecclesiastical discipline, than
if the ministers of teh churches, which
should be lights of the whole congre
gation, be fornicators or adulterous
persons. That offence especially above
all other, is an hinderaunce and blot to
al kind of honesty: but touching this I
purpose not at this time to discourse so
largely and fully as I might. to this
I adde, ye the band of wedlock is indis
soluble & everlasting, ye is to say, such a
knot as never can be undone. For of
fire is made one flesh and one bodye,
which if you sever, you do utterly mar
it. What God hath joyned together
therefore, let not ma separat. They ther
fore do make a slauhhter of this bodye,
that do comit adulterie. For ye lawes
of God and men admit a divorcement
betwixt a man & his adulterous wife.
And yet let not anye lesse or lighter
cause dissolve this knot betwixt man
and wife, than fornication is. Other
wise God which in the Gospell hath
permitted the lesse, doth not forbid the
greater to bee causes of divorcement.
And in the primitive church the Epi
stles & costitutions of christian princes

what largely out of the holy scripture, to the intent I might prove to al men, that wedlocke is holie, & that therefore no ma can be defiled with ye moderate, holie, & lawful use thereof: and so con sequently that marriage is permitted to al sorts of men. For ye Apostle saith: Let a bishoppe be the husband of one wife, let him rule his owne house wel, and have faithfull children. For it is manifest by ye testimonies of scripture and ecclesiasticall writers, that the A postles of Christ and other Apostolical teachers of ye primitive Church were married men, and had wives and chil dren. Neither is there any thing, next after corrupt doctrine, which doeth more infect the Church of Christ, and subvert al ecclesiastical discipline, than if the ministers of teh churches, which should be lights of the whole congre gation, be fornicators or adulterous persons. That offence especially above all other, is an hinderaunce and blot to al kind of honesty: but touching this I purpose not at this time to discourse so largely and fully as I might. to this I adde, ye the band of wedlock is indis soluble & everlasting, ye is to say, such a knot as never can be undone. For of fire is made one flesh and one bodye, which if you sever, you do utterly mar it. What God hath joyned together therefore, let not ma separat. They ther fore do make a slauhhter of this bodye, that do comit adulterie. For ye lawes of God and men admit a divorcement betwixt a man & his adulterous wife. And yet let not anye lesse or lighter cause dissolve this knot betwixt man and wife, than fornication is. Other wise God which in the Gospell hath permitted the lesse, doth not forbid the greater to bee causes of divorcement. And in the primitive church the Epi stles & costitutions of christian princes
do testifie, ye once comiting of fornicati
on was no cause of divorcement. Of
which I have spoken in another place.
But that this holy knot may be the
surer, it is availeable that marriages
be made holily, lawfully, and with dis
cretion in the feare of the Lorde. Let
them not be unwilling agreed unto
and made up by compulsio. First let ye
good liking of their consenting mindes
bee joyned in one, whom the open pro
session of natural consent & outwarde
hand-fasting must afterwarde couple
together. Let the be matched together,
that are not severed by alliaunce of
bloud, and nighnesse of affinitie. Let
them be coupled in one, that may ma
rie together by the lawes of God and
their coutrie, with the consent & coun
sel of their friends & parents. Let them
which minde marriage have a sincere
heart purposely bent to seek their own
safegard & continuall felicitie, that is,
to respect only the wil and pleasure of
God, and not admit anie evil affectios
as counsellers to make up ye marriage
betwixt them. Hierocles in his booke
De nuptys saith: It is meere follie and
lacke of wit which make those things
that of theselves are easie to be borne,
troublesome, and make a wife a gri
nous clog to her husband. For marri
age to many me hath bin intollerable:
not because the wedded state is by de
fault of it selfe or owne proper nature
so troublesome or comberous, but
for our matching as we shoulde not,
it falleth out as wee woulde not, and
causeth our marriages to bee grievous
and noysome. To this ende verily our
daily marriages doe commonly come.
For they marrie wives usually not
for the begetting of children or so
cietie of life: but some for a greate
dowrie, some for a beautifull bodye,
and some beeing seduced by suche

do testifie, ye once comiting of fornicati on was no cause of divorcement. Of which I have spoken in another place. But that this holy knot may be the surer, it is availeable that marriages be made holily, lawfully, and with dis cretion in the feare of the Lorde. Let them not be unwilling agreed unto and made up by compulsio. First let ye good liking of their consenting mindes bee joyned in one, whom the open pro session of natural consent & outwarde hand-fasting must afterwarde couple together. Let the be matched together, that are not severed by alliaunce of bloud, and nighnesse of affinitie. Let them be coupled in one, that may ma rie together by the lawes of God and their coutrie, with the consent & coun sel of their friends & parents. Let them which minde marriage have a sincere heart purposely bent to seek their own safegard & continuall felicitie, that is, to respect only the wil and pleasure of God, and not admit anie evil affectios as counsellers to make up ye marriage betwixt them. Hierocles in his booke De nuptys saith: It is meere follie and lacke of wit which make those things that of theselves are easie to be borne, troublesome, and make a wife a gri nous clog to her husband. For marri age to many me hath bin intollerable: not because the wedded state is by de fault of it selfe or owne proper nature so troublesome or comberous, but for our matching as we shoulde not, it falleth out as wee woulde not, and causeth our marriages to bee grievous and noysome. To this ende verily our daily marriages doe commonly come. For they marrie wives usually not for the begetting of children or so cietie of life: but some for a greate dowrie, some for a beautifull bodye, and some beeing seduced by suche
